components.name: eucanetd
components.description: Used to track component level items associated with Edge.

fields.summary: VPC nslookup failure to resolve instance's ip from within the VM

comments.body:
adding the following snippet from the parsed test output - specifically it appears that reverse DNS lookup for the instances' private IP, from within an instance, is not resolving (by euca DNS service) to the private instance hostname:

[2015-08-03 20:23:08,707] [i-8974a7ba] [DEBUG]: [root@10.116.132.100]# nslookup 172.31.1.113
[2015-08-03 20:23:08,819] [i-8974a7ba] [DEBUG]: 
Server:	10.111.1.70
Address:	10.111.1.70#53

** server can't find 113.1.31.172.in-addr.arpa.: NXDOMAIN

the request should be hitting the CLC as coming from the instances public address as the source IP.  I think we need a euca DNS service expert to consider this issue and recommend a path forward.

-dan
Instance DNS is not implemented for VPC ( EUCA-9952 )
Here we're shooting for EC2 classic-like behavior for forward and reverse name resolution. (Not for complete DNS semantics available under VPC on AWS, that's out of scope for 4.2.)
[~nurmi], to clarify, is it correct to say we will not provide any support for DNS to instances with only a private address in 4.2?

I think the main issue we will have is that reverse lookup of any private address:

* 10.0.0.0 - 10.255.255.255
* 172.16.0.0 - 172.31.255.255
* 192.168.0.0 - 192.168.255.255

must be supported as an instances private address. These private address ranges are likely to conflict with cloud addresses such as public/elastic IPs and cloud components, and also with cloud external address for other hosts within the datacenter.

AWS/EC2 DNS tests from instance in default VPC:

{code}
[ec2-user@ip-172-31-5-183 ~]$ # Instances public dns name
[ec2-user@ip-172-31-5-183 ~]$ dig ec2-52-8-137-203.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.30.rc1.38.amzn1 <<>> ec2-52-8-137-203.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 46605
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;ec2-52-8-137-203.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
ec2-52-8-137-203.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com. 60 IN	A 172.31.5.183

;; Query time: 1 msec
;; SERVER: 172.31.0.2#53(172.31.0.2)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  7 21:07:44 2015
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 82

[ec2-user@ip-172-31-5-183 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-172-31-5-183 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-172-31-5-183 ~]$ # Other public dns name
[ec2-user@ip-172-31-5-183 ~]$ dig ec2-52-8-137-204.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.30.rc1.38.amzn1 <<>> ec2-52-8-137-204.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com

;; ANSWER SECTION:

;; Query time: 2 msec
;; SERVER: 172.31.0.2#53(172.31.0.2)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  7 21:07:54 2015

[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-179 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-179 ~]$ # Reverse lookup for instances public DNS hostname
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-179 ~]$ dig -x 52.8.160.31

;; global options: +cmd

;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:

;; ANSWER SECTION:
31.160.8.52.in-addr.arpa. 300	IN	PTR	ec2-52-8-160-31.us-west-1.compute.amazonaws.com.

;; Query time: 5 msec
;; SERVER: 10.0.0.2#53(10.0.0.2)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  7 21:37:36 2015

;; SERVER: 10.0.0.2#53(10.0.0.2)

0.10.in-addr.arpa.	86400	IN	SOA	localhost. root.localhost. 2010102300 10800 900 604800 86400

AWS/EC2 DNS tests from instance in non-default VPC with DNS hostnames enabled:

{code}
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ # Instances private DNS name
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ dig ip-10-0-0-115.us-west-1.compute.internal

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.30.rc1.38.amzn1 <<>> ip-10-0-0-115.us-west-1.compute.internal
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 16323
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;ip-10-0-0-115.us-west-1.compute.internal. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
ip-10-0-0-115.us-west-1.compute.internal. 600 IN A 10.0.0.115

;; Query time: 0 msec
;; SERVER: 10.0.0.2#53(10.0.0.2)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  7 22:15:35 2015
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 74

[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ # Instances private IP reverse lookup
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ dig -x 10.0.0.115

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.30.rc1.38.amzn1 <<>> -x 10.0.0.115
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 46682
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;115.0.0.10.in-addr.arpa.	IN	PTR

;; ANSWER SECTION:
115.0.0.10.in-addr.arpa. 900	IN	PTR	ip-10-0-0-115.us-west-1.compute.internal.

;; Query time: 2 msec
;; SERVER: 10.0.0.2#53(10.0.0.2)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  7 22:15:52 2015
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 95

[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ # Random private DNS name (does not exist)
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ dig ip-10-10-10-115.us-west-1.compute.internal

; <<>> DiG 9.8.2rc1-RedHat-9.8.2-0.30.rc1.38.amzn1 <<>> ip-10-10-10-115.us-west-1.compute.internal
;; global options: +cmd
;; Got answer:
;; ->>HEADER<<- opcode: QUERY, status: NOERROR, id: 50159
;; flags: qr rd ra; QUERY: 1, ANSWER: 1, AUTHORITY: 0, ADDITIONAL: 0

;; QUESTION SECTION:
;ip-10-10-10-115.us-west-1.compute.internal. IN A

;; ANSWER SECTION:
ip-10-10-10-115.us-west-1.compute.internal. 900	IN A 10.10.10.115

;; Query time: 2 msec
;; SERVER: 10.0.0.2#53(10.0.0.2)
;; WHEN: Fri Aug  7 22:16:03 2015
;; MSG SIZE  rcvd: 76

[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
[ec2-user@ip-10-0-0-115 ~]$ 
{code}

Instance DNS is now partially supported for VPC. Our DNS behaviour does not change when the the VPC attributes are modified and the functionality does not match that of AWS/EC2 for enabled or disabled DNS hostnames. Instance DNS for private addresses will not work unless an instance has a public (or elastic) address.

The public DNS name is expected to resolve to the private address of an instance when resolved from the same network (within the same VPC), otherwise the public DNS name should resolve to the public address. Reverse lookup for the public and private addresses should result in the public or private DNS names respectively. Behaviour for public and private address collisions is problematic for reverse lookups, currently a private DNS name is returned but this is not ideal.

The recursive DNS resolver is impacted by this change as all private networks are now considered to be managed by eucalyptus and will not be supported for reverse lookups.

Looks like this test (instance suite DNSResolveTest) passed w/ VPC using today's build. 
Thanks!
-M
